bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to Talcott Williams, 14 December 1884
bibl.orgName: Estelle Doheny Collection of the Edward Laurence Doheny Memorial Library, St. John's Seminary

revisionDesc.change: transcribed, encoded and annotated from Miller.

body.p:
Upon the whole I shall have to beg off from Monday night. The doctor enjoins upon me that I am like an old wagon body—must keep rigidly to the smooth ordinarily traveled roads, & not cut across lots any how. Give my friendliest greetings & wishes to Miss Terry & Mr Irving—Should they, or either, feel any day—say from 2 to 3 in the afternoon—like calling upon me here, I should rate
it a welcome honor.
—If you have not procured the tickets before receiving this let them go unprocured—Best remembrances to Mrs. Williams.

postscript.p: Show this note to Miss Terry and Mr Irving—& if Miss T has the least desire to keep it, please let her do so.
